qas.question: During what period was the Muslim faith introduced to Somalia?
Along with Arabian influences, where did architectural influences come from in the medieval period?
In the medieval period, what buildings were notably built atop older ruins?
Along with sundried bricks and coral stone, what construction material was widely used after the introduction of Islam?
Before Islam was introduced, what was a common building material in Somalia?

context: The peaceful introduction of Islam in the <a0_0>early medieval<a0_0/> era of Somalia's history brought Islamic architectural influences from Arabia and <a1_0>Persia<a1_0/>. This had the effect of stimulating a shift in construction from <a4_0>drystone<a4_0/> and other related materials to coral stone, sundried bricks, and the widespread use of <a3_0>limestone<a3_0/> in Somali architecture. Many of the new architectural designs, such as <a2_0>mosques<a2_0/>, were built on the ruins of older structures. This practice would continue over and over again throughout the following centuries.
